comments.commentBody: Melissa Clark--this turkey was awesome! I accidentally cooked it to 175 degrees and it was still the most juicy turkey I have ever roasted. Along with your brandied pumpkin pie this made for a delicious turkey day.

In addition, there are knowledgeable commenters who write extremely well who have not been verified in spite of being popular and even getting editors' picks. I got my verification early (even though I waited a couple of years to accept it, just before you dropped the Facebook requirement) and in my special subject of climate have great respect, for example, for Lee Harrison.

The hierarchy is particularly biased towards those of us who were chosen early.

Susan Anderson, I agree with you one thousand percent about climate change. I don't agree that "truth" is (or should be) the criterion for getting a comment published in a comment thread at the NYT. The point of the comment thread - as well as the "verified" status, the "Times picks," etc. - is to allow the RANGE of reader opinions to appear. Getting a comment into a comment thread does not give a "New York Times imprimatur." It's a reader comments on an article that's all it is. Put another way, readers are allowed to be wrong (and plenty of 'em surely are).

I find it alarming, how many commenters think that views that align with their own are the only ones that should be allowed to appear.
DW, I don't ask that they agree with me.  I do ask that professional-grade disinformation be weeded out.

In the world of climate denial, the truth matters. The New York Times verification system appears to have no concern about the professional and industrial grade disinformation that several verified commenters present on climate. Their stuff looks like science, and it occupies a lot of time and energy of people who could be more creative were they set free from constantly providing references and pointing past outright lies cloaked in the appearance of legitimacy.

They need only be polite, literate, refrain from profanity and direct insult, and hey presto they get the NYTimes imprimatur.

I have been subjected to continuous harassment for years, and cannot ever point to climate information that confirms real science without instant correction from these people.

The truth matters. Content is more important than form.

I followed the instructions pretty carefully, but it hasn't gelled. Any tips?

It still tastes amazing!

FYI. The "counterproductive childish insults" that you are referring to, are not strictly the domain of the 'liberal community'. If you are interested in a global liberal commentary, that is equally founded on fact, I suggest you check out the UK version if The Guardian (www.theguardian.com).

We expect the likes of Ben Carson and Donald Trump and those on the far right to not have any serious proposals to address the mass migration of Syrians.

But, what is equally disappointing is that liberals appear equally irresponsible in not wanting to have a serious discussion about this pressing issue.

And just to inject a bit of reality for our liberal friends, please read this interesting commentary from Mother Jones magazine, which is well known for its liberal slant on the news.
http://www.motherjones.com/kevin-drum/2015/11/liberals-should-knock-mock...

Hopefully this article can help tone down the counterproductive childish insults that are so prevalent here and elsewhere in the liberal community, because those Syrians that do need our help deserve serious people coming together to solve this problem.

Mr. Kristol,
I would like to offer a temporary home to a Syrian refugee. I believe that we are partly responsible for the situation these people now find themselves. I am ashamed for the states whose governors rescinded their states' hospitality. The candidates who practice demagoguery are not worthy of holding any office let alone the presidency. I wish Heba and her family well. None of them asked for this.

Hallus comes from classical Latin. Here Sextus Pompeius Festus defines it as "pollex pedis," "thumb of the foot."
http://tinyurl.com/oqqoq6y

.
Scientific code-speak is pretty much the reason I don't raise much ruckus about "crosswordese". Once I've gotten through trying to decipher some medical report so as to help a relative make medical decisions, or understand what an insurance company will or won't cover, "etui" and "Omoo" are mere bags of shell.

These medical types are probably upset that the typical human has only one "appendix". Deprives them of an excuse to say "appendices". I wonder if there is a recognized dialect called "Medical Latin"? I once saw a reference to "Law French" -- possibly upon researching crossword favorite "assize", although I really don't recall.
Neither, he's a bona fide madman.

This tale of woe will not register with the public Trump. He's got a quasi-conservative constituency to appeal to and they eat up the "no Syrian refugees" hate mongering. Anyone with any commonsense wants to protect our country from the possibility of terrorists coming in disguised as a frightened, desperate refugee. However, the vetting sounds good and maybe it could be tweaked to make it nearly airtight and then we should succor these poor, suffering people. I bet that Trump has a heart and when he isn't out in front of his fans, in a private moment he realizes that his public pronouncements about refugees are morally repugnant and cruel. On the other hand, maybe he is a morally repugnant and cruel man.

Starting to look forward to Friday puzzles. This one did not disappoint.
Had not heard of the YO MAMA JOKE genre before, nor of ECKO. Rest of the names were familiar, especially ELMO, OHARA, JEB, MIA ,NO SIREE BOB-- the last one is known around here as "Robert", though.

Now for this - and I hope not to hoist my own PETARD (or to be "Martinized ") *. The Hartford logo is a red deer stag, not an ELK.
While the red deer and elks were considered at one time to be the same species, in 1998 genetic studies showed them to be two distinct species.

* Martin- you just commented re "halluces", so you are not just LURKing...
How was your dinner and clean-up? What was the menu? Did it include some Napa CABS ? And some STIFF DRINKs?

Nice puzzle with great clues.

Commercial animal cloning by these companies could have benefits, but there are costs too both to society and to the animals involved. For instance in dog cloning for pets the techniques involved essentially require the deaths of some dogs to make the clones. The same is probably true for cow clones. It's important to have a balanced discussion of the possible costs/risks and benefits as well as to consider the ethical questions, especially in the context of for-profits rather than just research. I've written more on these kinds of considerations: http://www.ipscell.com/2015/10/noahs-gmo-ark-is-it-ethical-to-create-gm-...
Paul Knoepfler
Associate Professor
UC Davis

This came out just awful! The spices totally overpowered all other flavors and I didn't care for the Pinot flavor either. I doubled the recipe and used ground spices (checking equivalents) so it is possible I just used too much. Fortunately, I had all the ingredients on hand for another recipe I've made before and it was a big hit: https://food52.com/recipes/1467-pear-brandy-and-walnut-cranberry-sauce
It makes a beautiful presentation but is bland.  It's easy to make if you use a mandoline.  I might make it again but only if there is a variation that will make a more exciting flavor.

Added sautéed leeks and for that extra 1/4 cup of creme fraiche I went with greek yogurt.  Excellent, easy, delicious, and looks super impressive!

New Jersey may call its sectional champions state champions, but there is no state wide public school championship competition. The four group classes (grouped by school size) crown champions in South Jersey, Central Jersey, North Jersey A and B. The smaller number of parochial schools allows for state wide group champions. New Jersey, despite being a densely populated state has lots of small high schools. Schools of 300-500 students play football against similar sized schools.
Also, I am a graduate and fan of the U of Utah and am a vocal critic of disparaging ethnic team mascots (see the Potomac Drainage Basin Indigenous Peoples). The Northern Ute nation, as well as the Chippewa Nation and Seminole Nation all have agreed to allow their tribes to be offical mascots of Division I schools. Utah's agreement is updated periodically and the U has considered changing mascots if the tribe objects. The costumed mascot of the U teams is a red tailed hawk, not a painted, feathered Indian warrior. GE's picture is of a fan, and fans have the right and freedom to be idiots.

I want to add an update: I fixed the crust by making more dough & adding in on to the top for the 2nd half of the crust baking.  It looked quite "rustic", but that was kind of charming.  The rest of the pie was a breeze! It cooked beautifully (no rising, so make sure you fill it all the way). The cutting off of the crust with a serrated knife was difficult as a lot of crust crumbled, but that added to the rustic look.  The filling stayed firm when cut, and it tasted amazing!

Yes, harm or death from other sources exist, and are perhaps statistically more likely. By that logic, until any threat gets to definite critical size, we should take no security precautions. Genius. What is really exhausting is op-Ed pieces like this one that tries to minimize and belittle a legitimate concern -,the concept of properly screening those entering the country, particularly those that fit a certain profile (gasp, then get over it) - by using Trump's acerbic personality and hyperbolic statements, to paint anybody in favor of common sense with the bigot brush.
Trump is not the problem. Heba is not the problem. A lax visa system, and gaps in U.S. Intelligence in particular locations - like Syria - are problems. Made a little worse by op-Ed pieces like this one that pluck the heartstrings and ignore bigger issues.

The recipe as written does not work. There is not enough moisture for the amount of bread. I used canned oysters and ended up using four cans (I originally planned on using two), plus the juice from all four, and that still wasn't enough. I added another 1/2 cup of chicken broth as well as two slightly beaten eggs. I was almost happy with the final result. This is a good starting point, but not a good recipe overall.
I tried your variation, but added a splash of spiced moonshine instead of vanilla. It flavor worked out ok, but the brown sugar was a little grainy for my liking.

Walter, the idea of continuous growth is killing our fellow creatures. Human numbers are causing the sixth mass extinction of non-human life on Earth. This is separate from global warming, although CO2 pollution will just make it worse in the future. The only way to save the flora and fauna is to let human population decrease, especially in developed countries which use large amounts of resources and create a lot of pollution, even in areas where there are no humans.

Americans persist in waving the Trumpeter' s flag for him regardless of the stupidity of doing so. What will it take to pry their cold, dead fingers from that decrepit flagpole before their flesh adheres to its moldy remains and it is declared dead along with its adherents? Too much, I'm afraid.
Dan. I agree that  it doesn't, when the "a" is not sounded, but in Pharaoh, after the long a-sound - before or after the "r" - there shouldn't be any doubt left.
This was great! I did not have stock and used water. I also omitted the wine. Result was a simple, perfect, classic gravy that tasted wonderfully of Turkey!
